story:
Help Cork Out!


Our friend and Rochester's own Ryan O'Rourke has been very sick lately. So sick, that he has found himself back in the hospital and out of work. He has been diagnosed with Crohn's disease. He is like most of us, living pay check to pay check, which means any extensive time out of work can be very scary. Also, he is not covered under his employers health insurance and he currently doesn't have his own.

So, we are asking all of our friends in the bicycle community of Rochester and all over the world to help Cork out in any way, shape, or form. He is a total badass of bike rider and an even cooler friend so lets all show him some love and support!!

The Run Down

So, the deal is, Cork was sent to the hospital on July 23rd. He had already been out of work for a couple of weeks before that. He most likely will be out of work for quite a long time. It would be awesome to raise a few grand for him so he can actually take care of his bills. A bunch of us in Rochester came together to get the ball rolling on getting Cork some cash.  'The Yea's' own Matt Smith came up with the Corgi Pentagram design that we will be using for our 'perks', which are explained below:


The 'Perks' we would like to offer in return for your generosity are:

$5 - $5 for 5!

For a $5 pledge, you get ... a High 5! You can help share the stoke with a major rager of a high five from one of the members of the Hacksaw crew. Any little bit helps out Cork and if $5 is all you got, then you'll get one hell of a high 5 in return!

$10 - 1 'Cork Is My HomeDawg' Sticker!

For a $10 pledge, you get your very own 'Cork Is My HomeDawg' Sticker. Let the world know that you give a crap about a friend in need and that the bike community is huge and strong!

$20 - 1 'Cork Is My HomeDawg'  T Shirt!

For a $20 pledge, you get your very own 'Cork Is My HomeDawg' T Shirt. This is a great way to step your support game up and rockin' the hell out of this design. You will be the envy of all of your cheapskate friends who don't have one because all the girls will sweating you as you shred the Bug Jar's dance floor in style in this exclusive t-shirt. You are guaranteed to get laid in this thing.*

*We guarantee nothing.

$25 - Combo of a 'CIMHD' T Shirt AND Sticker!!

For a $25 pledge, you get the combo of the two, a Cork T Shirt AND Sticker. So Sick! Enough Said.

$50 - A 'CIMHD' T Shirt, Sticker, AND an Outlaw Boards Gift Certificate!!

For a $50 pledge, you get a Cork T Shirt, Sticker, and a $10 gift certificate to Outlaw Boards in Canandaigua, NY. Cork rides for this Shop and the owners, Reez and Mike May, are some righteous dudes. Only 5 of these available, so get them while they are hot!

$100 - Win a Date with Dave Raffa!

Yes, ladies and lady boys, if you shell out a cool $100, you will win yourself a nice evening with Rochester's own uncut hunk, Dave Raffa. He will most likely take you out on a nice romantic bike ride to the closest bar having it's 'Cheap Wing Night' special. He will be a gentleman and pay for your drinks, as long as you are drinking whatever the $8 pitcher special is that night. I know, romantic as hell, right?!

And if we don't raise our goal, we will still be giving ALL of the proceeds (after indigogo takes it's small percentage cut) to  Cork directly.

The Impact

Crohn’s disease is a chronic inflammatory condition of the gastrointestinal tract. This is Cork's second stint with this gnarly disease.  This time around he lost 10 lbs. in the first week.  It's a very serious disease that is better explained here:

http://www.ccfa.org/what-are-crohns-and-colitis/what-is-crohns-disease/

Hey, He's our bud. Let's help him out. Any little bit you can contribute will help.

Our friend and Rochester's own Ryan O'Rourke has been very sick lately. So sick, that he has found himself back in the hospital and out of work. He has been diagnosed with Crohn's disease. He is like most of us, living pay check to pay check, which means any extensive time out of work can be very scary. Also, he is not covered under his employers health insurance and he currently doesn't have his own. 
So, we are asking all of our friends in the bicycle community of Rochester and all over the world to help Cork out in any way, shape, or form. He is a total badass of bike rider and an even cooler friend so lets all show him some love and support!!
The Run Down
So, the deal is, Cork was sent to the hospital on July 23rd. He had already been out of work for a couple of weeks before that. He most likely will be out of work for quite a long time. It would be awesome to raise a few grand for him so he can actually take care of his bills. A bunch of us in Rochester came together to get the ball rolling on getting Cork some cash.  'The Yea's' own Matt Smith came up with the Corgi Pentagram design that we will be using for our 'perks', which are explained below:

The 'Perks' we would like to offer in return for your generosity are:$5 - $5 for 5!
For a $5 pledge, you get ... a High 5! You can help share the stoke with a major rager of a high five from one of the members of the Hacksaw crew. Any little bit helps out Cork and if $5 is all you got, then you'll get one hell of a high 5 in return!$10 - 1 'Cork Is My HomeDawg' Sticker!
For a $10 pledge, you get your very own 'Cork Is My HomeDawg' Sticker. Let the world know that you give a crap about a friend in need and that the bike community is huge and strong! 

$20 - 1 'Cork Is My HomeDawg'  T Shirt!
For a $20 pledge, you get your very own 'Cork Is My HomeDawg' T Shirt. This is a great way to step your support game up and rockin' the hell out of this design. You will be the envy of all of your cheapskate friends who don't have one because all the girls will sweating you as you shred the Bug Jar's dance floor in style in this exclusive t-shirt. You are guaranteed to get laid in this thing.*
*We guarantee nothing.

$25 - Combo of a 'CIMHD' T Shirt AND Sticker!!

For a $25 pledge, you get the combo of the two, a Cork T Shirt AND Sticker. So Sick! Enough Said.

$50 - A 'CIMHD' T Shirt, Sticker, AND an Outlaw Boards Gift Certificate!!For a $50 pledge, you get a Cork T Shirt, Sticker, and a $10 gift certificate to Outlaw Boards in Canandaigua, NY. Cork rides for this Shop and the owners, Reez and Mike May, are some righteous dudes. Only 5 of these available, so get them while they are hot! 
$100 - Win a Date with Dave Raffa!


Yes, ladies and lady boys, if you shell out a cool $100, you will win yourself a nice evening with Rochester's own uncut hunk, Dave Raffa. He will most likely take you out on a nice romantic bike ride to the closest bar having it's 'Cheap Wing Night' special. He will be a gentleman and pay for your drinks, as long as you are drinking whatever the $8 pitcher special is that night. I know, romantic as hell, right?!And if we don't raise our goal, we will still be giving ALL of the proceeds (after indigogo takes it's small percentage cut) to  Cork directly.  The ImpactCrohn’s disease is a chronic inflammatory condition of the gastrointestinal tract. This is Cork's second stint with this gnarly disease.  This time around he lost 10 lbs. in the first week.  It's a very serious disease that is better explained here:http://www.ccfa.org/what-are-crohns-and-colitis/what-is-crohns-disease/Hey, He's our bud. Let's help him out. Any little bit you can contribute will help.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Hello!

My name is Jonas Corona and I am seeking help to get the training I need to take my game to the next level.  I am 11-years-old, and I am from Long Beach, CA. You may know my work through my charitable organization Love in the Mirror, but I would like to tell you a little about my second passion - playing tennis.

I began playing tennis the same year I began volunteering, when I was 4-years-old. Besides helping out in my community, I love playing tennis. I play 6-8 hours of tennis per day and compete in 3-4 tournaments per month.  Most of the tournaments are held at prestigious members only country clubs throughout Los Angeles and Orange counties.

In the fall, I will be entering the 6th grade and will be homeschooled to allow time to take my training to the next level. I am looking forward to competing nationally and internationally in the future. Currently I am a  student in the Valter Paiva Tennis Academy at the Billie Jean King Tennis Center in Long Beach, CA. I have also been a part of the Orange County League Champion team for USTA Jr. Team Tennis for the past few seasons. Most recently I attended a Jr. Tennis Summer Camp each morning and a Jr. Academy every afternoon during the entire summer.

Although I have been lucky to have a great family and coach who support me, I am unable to take my training to the next level. The costs associated with an increase in my personal training schedule, tournament fees and travel expenses are more than I can afford. I am at the age where it is crucial to begin serious training, and I fear that without your help, I will not be able to continue following my dream of becoming a tennis professional.

Considering all the above said, I kindly request you to consider sponsoring me so I may increase my training and begin to represent my city at sectional and national tournaments in the near future. I would be very grateful to you, if you sponsor me. You will help me realize my dream of becoming a tennis champion.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help me get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tool
  • Visit my charity website to see what change I am making in my community at www.loveinthemirror.org
  • Become a corporate sponsor with perks *ask for more details

story: Running the plymouth half marathon again this year but this time for the Dan Payne memorial fund. Me and Tom ran last year for cancer research but I'd like to raise money this year for Dans charity. Dan was the first person to donate to mine and Toms page last year which speaks volumes about the kind of person Dan was. Couldn't have wished for a better mate to grow up with. Dan and his family are the most generous people I know. I'd really appreciate it if you could be as generous as them and give a little bit, as this fund means a lot to people who were close to dan. Anything you do give, no matter how much, will be hugely appreciated. The money donated to the fund, created by Dans family, will be used to aid cancer patients throughtout their illness. Money will also go to teenage cancer trust and cancer research.

story:
If our aging water tanks fail,  we'll lose our golf course.

The Powell Golf Club needs your help raising funds so it can renovate its course irrigation water storage facilities.
Two storage tanks are the lifeblood of the course, feeding water throughout the arid high desert landscape — but they are more than 50 years old and deteriorating. 
They must be replaced before they fail. 

Before tending to the deteriorating tanks, the board must first retire its $100,000 bank note.

The club's debt was taken on in two massive undertakings — the expansion from 9 to 18 holes in 1994, and the re-design of the original 9-hole greens in 2003. The course also faced multiple tough revenue years following the loss of many of the greens to winter-kill the winter of 2007-08. 
The board has since invested in synthetic greens covers for protection during the off season. The covers have proven to be the answer that now help the greens survive northwest Wyoming's bitter cold winters. 

Fundraising efforts to date... and additional plans for 2015.

Since 2011, the Powell Golf Club Board has worked tirelessly to reduce the club's debt from $260,000 to just $100,000.

The City of Powell plays a key role with its "Matching Funds Program." Dollar for dollar, the city will match donations to the club earmarked for debt retirement. Taking advantage of this tremendous opportunity, a number of Powell area businesses have purchased commercial sponsorship signs to be placed on the 18 stone tee markers at each hole. These commitments are for three years, with a possible total of $24,000 per year with all 18 holes sponsored. To date, commitments have been received for more than half of the hole sponsorships. The City of Powell's match of these contributions could  bring that total to $48,000 per year, or $144,000 for three years.

This fall, Powell Golf Club plans to host its annual Debt Reduction Fundraiser Golf Tournament. All proceeds from this event are also available for match by the city.  

Our crowd funding campaign goal is $15,000. If you help us reach this goal, nearly $24,000 total will be raised after the City of Powell "matching Funds Program." Choose one of the awesome perks and watch your donation help Powell Golf Club grow! 

With the matching funds program, our crowdfunding effort, the hole sponsorship opportunities and debt reduction golf tournament, we hope to wipe out the $100,000 note. By retiring that debt, the club can focus on improvements to the irrigation system, ensuring the course thrives in the future.

More than $50,000 raised annually for local organizations and youth!

Our 18-hole golf course helps local organizations raise top dollars. 

Since 1993, The Powell Golf Club has hosted the Powell Medical Foundation's annual "Heartland Classic" fundraiser golf tournament. In those 22 years, the foundation has raised a whopping $190,000 from the annual events. More than $20,000 was raised in the 2014 tournament alone. 

 The annual fundraiser event for Northwest College's Trapper Booster Club, the "Trapper Bonanza" golf tournament, is an old favorite. In the past four years, it has generated more than $30,000 to support Northwest College athletes, surpassing the $10,000 mark in 2014. The "Trapper Bonanza" tournament has been helping recruit student athletes and provide extra athletic gear for more than 30 years.

There are numerous other local organizations which can boast similar numbers ...

Simply put, the funds raised at Powell Golf Club are turned back within our community to support the various organizations’ causes. Teams, clubs and businesses understand the vital role the course plays in their fundraising success. Select a perk and help us ensure Powell Golf Club delivers the green!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some may not be able to give money toward our project. If you feel passionate about our campaign and you want to help in other ways, become a fan of our Facebook page http://www.facebook.com/powellgolfclub and share our request with your friends. Don't use Facebook? No Problem! Simply copy and paste this link http://igg.me/at/growpowellgolf and share our story through email to the addresses in your list of contacts. 

Spread the news and help us Keep Powell Golf Club Green in 2015!

story:
Cresilda and Baby Joy are two Filipina domestic workers in Hong Kong who were dismissed from employment shortly after being diagnosed with breast cancer. As a result of losing their jobs, they no longer qualify for treatment in government hospitals at Hong Kong resident rates. The medical fees they are being charged by the hospital for cancer treatment are prohibitively expensive.

This is a joint campaign by Helpers for Domestic Helpers, a Hong Kong charity which is helping them to both raise enough money for medical treatment and to take their employers to court for suspected disability discrimination.

Three weeks ago, a fund raising campaign was launched in Indiegogo to support Cresilda’s cancer treatment. For those who had not seen her profile, Cresilda is a 38 year old single mother of 3 children who has been working in Hong Kong since 2011.

The doctors at the Queen Mary Hospital devised a treatment plan involving shrinking her tumour with aggressive target chemotherapy, a mastectomy then radiotherapy.  Generous donors on Hong Kong Moms and around the world raised more than HK$100,000 for her treatment. Thanks to this, Cresilda had her first chemotherapy session on 4th December. The money donated so far will cover one more chemotherapy session but it has now been realized that the total cost of the treatment is likely to be in the region of HK$500,000. She urgently needs more funds to enable her to continue this life-saving treatment.

Baby Joy is a 41 year old Filipina, who has been working as a domestic helper in Hong Kong since 2011. She is the sole breadwinner in her family, providing for her elderly parents, her brothers and sisters and an adopted son aged 10 years.

Babyjoy is also being seen by the doctors at Queen Mary Hospital who have devised a treatment plan involving chemotherapy treatment and surgery. Through generous donors in Hong Kong, Baby Joy has received around HK$35,000 towards her treatment and was able to have her first chemotherapy session on 2nd December. The money donated so far will cover about 2 more chemotherapy sessions, but she needs 6 in total (the last 3 sessions involving more expensive drugs) followed by surgery. Like Cresilda, she urgently needs more funds to enable her to continue this life-saving treatment which has been estimated to cost around HK$275,000.

Please, help us help these ladies and donate what you can.

story:
Short Summary

As a beekeeper, winter is difficult. In the northern US, it can last many months leaving hours and hours to ponder; “I wonder how my bees are doing?”

To answer that question for me and other beekeeping enthusiasts like me, our team designed the BroodMinder.

The BroodMinder is a professional-grade monitor expressly designed for the apiarist. Drawing on our many years of consumer and scientific product design, we have created a device that accurately logs hive temperature and humidity every hour for two years.

When coupled with our iPhone or Android app, it creates a system in which, in a few seconds, the overwintering state of your bee yard may be assessed.


Update - April 2016 

You may be here because you saw an article in Bee Culture or another blog or from the BroodMinder-W campaign that we just initiated. We're really happy that you found us.

Two weeks after the distribution of our first BroodMinder device, Texas Instruments (TI) recalled the humidity sensor we used because it was inaccurate in a high humidity environment. SIEP#57 recall also fessed up that the sensor would drift up 15% in 18 months. This was devastating news to get.

The BroodMinder-TH Gen 2 device has dropped the TI sensor entirely and incorporated a Sensirion humidity sensor which TI admitted was best in class according to their competitive analysis. We have tested it extensively and found it to be excellent.

We are doing a full recall and will ship, free of charge, replacements to anyone returning the Gen 1 devices. We anticipate delivery beginning June 1st. 

We stand fully behind our products with absolute loyalty to our customers.

Please check out our new Indiegogo campaign for the BroodMinder-W beehive scale at igg.me/at/BroodMinder.

We do our best to keep BroodMinder owners and interested parties up to date with the status of the company and products. You will find a link under the contact us page on our website, BroodMinder.com or click HERE to go directly to the sign up page.

We also encourage you to check out our strategic partner beekeeping.io. They are warehousing all of the BroodMinder data and providing free/public access to it. You can log in as user:broodminder, password:broodminder and look around the beta test area.

Update for the Final Week of the Campaign (November 2015)

I went into this venture believing that all I wanted was a way to see if my bees were happy throughout the winter. After speaking with many beekeepers during the launch, my beliefs have shifted.

During the last 10 years the US has been averaging 30% hive loss over winter. Last winter, across the mid-west numerous states lost more than 60%. Regularly losing that much livestock in any other agriculture venture would be unfathomable. It drives me crazy.

The BroodMinder team has developed a professional grade temperature and humidity monitor expressly for beehives. The entire team has worked hard to lower the barrier for entry so that the every bee enthusiast may be part of this national experiment. We see a great will on the part of beekeepers to contribute to solving this problem as well as understanding more about their personal hives.

The BroodMinder team believes that by performing simple, uniform measurements on thousands of hives, the beekeeping community will gain insights into hive distress and we will be able to develop interventions to improve outcomes. 

Honeybees are under increasing pressure from many things in their environment. Everything from monocultures to neonicotinoids. As public awareness of the stress and importance of bees has grown, scores of new bee enthusiasts have been born. We see this group as a new and enthusiastic resource to expand the world’s knowledge base.

In order to encourage community participation, BroodMinder is committed to providing free software upgrades and data storage to any purchaser who agrees to share their hive data on our public repository. (For privacy reasons, only zip codes will be used to identify location.) This data, collected in a uniform manner will be made available to anyone who would like to analyze it.


History Area

The rest of this page documents the campaign as we ended it. We are happy to say that we shipped 500 units in December and have users all over the USA and the world. Here is the installation map for the USA. 


What We Need 

Achieving a 1000+ build quantity reduces the overall cost by 30%. This in turn makes the device much more affordable for enthusiast bee keepers. We need $20,000 to cover the tooling and initial build.

What You Get

There are four options on how you can help.

For $10 we will send you an uber-cute bottlecap bee button, designed by the good folks at bb7. The button is held in place by a pair of magnets so that you can sport it on your blouse or jacket or use it on the refrigerator to hold up your honey-do lists.


For $40, you will receive a BroodMinder. You can see many more details at BroodMinder.com. $40 is our wholesale cost. You will receive one of first units produced in time for Holiday gift giving. It comes in an attractive package that would delight even the likes of Steve Jobs or Jony Ives.

For $60, you will receive a BroodMinder plus free eternal software upgrades. We have a lot of advanced features on the road map and, as an early adopter, you will receive them all as they are released. There is software in the works for keeping hive "logbooks" as well as graphing and analysis programs. Note: If you share your hive data on the public repository, we will provide you these upgrades for free.

  

At this point, a week before the end of the campaign, we have our funding assured by an patron willing to make up any shortfall. Production is progressing with an eye towards a December 1st ship date.  Here is a video of the boards getting made.

is a 

The Impact

Honeybees are under increasing pressure from many things in their environment. Everything from monocultures to neonicotinoids. As public awareness of the stress on and importance of bees has grown, scores of new bee enthusiasts have been born.

However, beekeeping, while rewarding, is not simple. As a new beekeeper, I lost more than one hive to winter.  Losing hives doesn't really help the world's bee population; it mostly helps the suppliers of bees.

The BroodMinder measures temperature and humidity inside the hive. Why is this important? Hives are lost for numerous reasons, some of which could be prevented.

In the winter, the worker bees form a ball around the queen. This generates heat and protects the queen.  We can monitor that temperature as it drifts to the top of the hive. If the beekeeper sees it drop, it indicates the bee population is dwindling.

More times than not, it is simply that the bees have run out of food. That can be solved by adding things like sugar boards.

The other prevalent problem is humidity inside the hive. Under some circumstances, when the humidity is too high, condensation will form on the ceiling of the brood chamber and rain down on the brood. It's not hard to see how unpleasant and deadly this would be.  When this happens, re-configuring the hive ventilation is called for. That's where reaching out to experienced beekeepers for help can save your hive.

Now, you might think that all one has to do is lift the lid and look inside.  No way. That is the equivalent to taking the polar bear plunge when it is freezing outside. Looking inside wirelessly solves this problem.

Likewise you might think, why this? There are scores of thermometers available. We have designed this device with a few particular features important to beekeepers.

  • Very low radio power. We don't want to risk any effect on the bees so we are using Class 3, Blue Tooth Low Energy, the standardized lowest transmit power.
  • Long battery life and long data log. Logging the data for over a year will be very useful for knowing the health of the hive and having actionable data for the coming year.
  • Bee friendly housing. Beehives are crowded with only 1/4" gaps. The BroodMinder is packaged in a thin, safe wrapper that the bees won't destroy.
  • Simple operation. We have better things to do than futz around with our phones. The total installation process takes less than a minute with no passwords or device pairing dances. It just works!

 If we can get this product off the ground, it will launch a company, dedicated to the well being of honeybees. This has become a passion for me over the last eight years and the team and I crave the opportunity to create useful, purposeful devices that have a impact on the honeybee population.

The model 42 BroodMinder is targeted for overwinter monitoring. If we can make this a go, then follow-up products will include devices to monitor hives year-round. Product number two will be a simple and inexpensive wireless device to monitor and log the weight of your hive.

Risks & Challenges

The team is well down the development path. We have working prototypes and software. We have also worked hard to mitigate risk by using production partners with many years of product development experience.

However... there are always risks.

The primary risk is not making the schedule. Many of us have been contributors to programs that are continually "almost there'. All I can say to this is that we see a launch window for the device that opens once per year during the fall season. December is the best time to start establishing a baseline for your hive. We are motivated to get there and start saving bees!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help financially, then please pass this campaign on to your beekeeping friends. We are counting on word of mouth and passing of information between beekeeping clubs and enthusiasts.
story_txt:
Short Summary As a beekeeper, winter is difficult. In the northern US, it can last many months leaving hours and hours to ponder; “I wonder how my bees are doing?”
To answer that question for me and other beekeeping enthusiasts like me, our team designed the BroodMinder.

The BroodMinder is a professional-grade monitor expressly designed for the apiarist. Drawing on our many years of consumer and scientific product design, we have created a device that accurately logs hive temperature and humidity every hour for two years.
When coupled with our iPhone or Android app, it creates a system in which, in a few seconds, the overwintering state of your bee yard may be assessed.



Update - April 2016 
You may be here because you saw an article in Bee Culture or another blog or from the BroodMinder-W campaign that we just initiated. We're really happy that you found us.
Two weeks after the distribution of our first BroodMinder device, Texas Instruments (TI) recalled the humidity sensor we used because it was inaccurate in a high humidity environment. SIEP#57 recall also fessed up that the sensor would drift up 15% in 18 months. This was devastating news to get.
The BroodMinder-TH Gen 2 device has dropped the TI sensor entirely and incorporated a Sensirion humidity sensor which TI admitted was best in class according to their competitive analysis. We have tested it extensively and found it to be excellent.
We are doing a full recall and will ship, free of charge, replacements to anyone returning the Gen 1 devices. We anticipate delivery beginning June 1st. 
We stand fully behind our products with absolute loyalty to our customers.
Please check out our new Indiegogo campaign for the BroodMinder-W beehive scale at igg.me/at/BroodMinder.


We do our best to keep BroodMinder owners and interested parties up to date with the status of the company and products. You will find a link under the contact us page on our website, BroodMinder.com or click HERE to go directly to the sign up page.

We also encourage you to check out our strategic partner beekeeping.io. They are warehousing all of the BroodMinder data and providing free/public access to it. You can log in as user:broodminder, password:broodminder and look around the beta test area.


Update for the Final Week of the Campaign (November 2015)

I went into this venture believing that all I wanted was a
way to see if my bees were happy throughout the winter. After speaking
with many beekeepers during the launch, my beliefs have shifted.
During the last 10 years the US has been
averaging 30% hive loss over winter. Last winter, across the
mid-west numerous states lost more than 60%. Regularly losing that much
livestock in any other agriculture venture would be unfathomable. It drives me
crazy.
The BroodMinder team has developed a professional grade
temperature and humidity monitor expressly for beehives. The entire team has
worked hard to lower the barrier for entry so that the every bee enthusiast may
be part of this national experiment. We see a great will on the part of
beekeepers to contribute to solving this problem as well as understanding more
about their personal hives.
The BroodMinder team believes that by performing simple,
uniform measurements on thousands of hives, the beekeeping community will
gain insights into hive distress and we will be able to develop interventions
to improve outcomes. 
Honeybees are under increasing pressure from many things in
their environment. Everything from monocultures to neonicotinoids. As public
awareness of the stress and importance of bees has grown, scores of new bee
enthusiasts have been born. We see this group as a new and enthusiastic
resource to expand the world’s knowledge base.
In order to encourage community participation, BroodMinder
is committed to providing free software upgrades and data storage to any
purchaser who agrees to share their hive data on our public repository. (For
privacy reasons, only zip codes will be used to identify location.) This data,
collected in a uniform manner will be made available to anyone who would like
to analyze it.


History AreaThe rest of this page documents the campaign as we ended it. We are happy to say that we shipped 500 units in December and have users all over the USA and the world. Here is the installation map for the USA. 


What We Need 
Achieving a 1000+ build quantity reduces the overall cost by 30%. This in turn makes the device much more affordable for enthusiast bee keepers. We need $20,000 to cover the tooling and initial build.
What You Get
There are four options on how you can help.
For $10 we will send you an uber-cute bottlecap bee button, designed by the good folks at bb7. The button is held in place by a pair of magnets so that you can sport it on your blouse or jacket or use it on the refrigerator to hold up your honey-do lists.


For $40, you will receive a BroodMinder. You can see many more details at BroodMinder.com. $40 is our wholesale cost. You will receive one of first units produced in time for Holiday gift giving. It comes in an attractive package that would delight even the likes of Steve Jobs or Jony Ives.



For $60, you will receive a BroodMinder plus free eternal software upgrades. We have a lot of advanced features on the road map and, as an early adopter, you will receive them all as they are released. There is software in the works for keeping hive "logbooks" as well as graphing and analysis programs. Note: If you share your hive data on the public repository, we will provide you these upgrades for free.


  At this point, a week before the end of the campaign, we have our funding assured by an patron willing to make up any shortfall. Production is progressing with an eye towards a December 1st ship date.  Here is a video of the boards getting made.is a 
The Impact

Honeybees are under increasing pressure from many things in their environment. Everything from monocultures to neonicotinoids. As public awareness of the stress on and importance of bees has grown, scores of new bee enthusiasts have been born.
However, beekeeping, while rewarding, is not simple. As a new beekeeper, I lost more than one hive to winter.  Losing hives doesn't really help the world's bee population; it mostly helps the suppliers of bees.
The BroodMinder measures temperature and humidity inside the hive. Why is this important? Hives are lost for numerous reasons, some of which could be prevented.
In the winter, the worker bees form a ball around the queen. This generates heat and protects the queen.  We can monitor that temperature as it drifts to the top of the hive. If the beekeeper sees it drop, it indicates the bee population is dwindling.
More times than not, it is simply that the bees have run out of food. That can be solved by adding things like sugar boards.
The other prevalent problem is humidity inside the hive. Under some circumstances, when the humidity is too high, condensation will form on the ceiling of the brood chamber and rain down on the brood. It's not hard to see how unpleasant and deadly this would be.  When this happens, re-configuring the hive ventilation is called for. That's where reaching out to experienced beekeepers for help can save your hive.
Now, you might think that all one has to do is lift the lid and look inside.  No way. That is the equivalent to taking the polar bear plunge when it is freezing outside. Looking inside wirelessly solves this problem.




Likewise you might think, why this? There are scores of thermometers available. We have designed this device with a few particular features important to beekeepers.


Very low radio power. We don't want to risk any effect on the bees so we are using Class 3, Blue Tooth Low Energy, the standardized lowest transmit power.
Long battery life and long data log. Logging the data for over a year will be very useful for knowing the health of the hive and having actionable data for the coming year.
Bee friendly housing. Beehives are crowded with only 1/4" gaps. The BroodMinder is packaged in a thin, safe wrapper that the bees won't destroy.
Simple operation. We have better things to do than futz around with our phones. The total installation process takes less than a minute with no passwords or device pairing dances. It just works!

 If we can get this product off the ground, it will launch a company, dedicated to the well being of honeybees. This has become a passion for me over the last eight years and the team and I crave the opportunity to create useful, purposeful devices that have a impact on the honeybee population.
The model 42 BroodMinder is targeted for overwinter monitoring. If we can make this a go, then follow-up products will include devices to monitor hives year-round. Product number two will be a simple and inexpensive wireless device to monitor and log the weight of your hive.
    Risks & Challenges The team is well down the development path. We have working prototypes and software. We have also worked hard to mitigate risk by using production partners with many years of product development experience.
However... there are always risks.
The primary risk is not making the schedule. Many of us have been contributors to programs that are continually "almost there'. All I can say to this is that we see a launch window for the device that opens once per year during the fall season. December is the best time to start establishing a baseline for your hive. We are motivated to get there and start saving bees!
    Other Ways You Can Help If you can't help financially, then please pass this campaign on to your beekeeping friends. We are counting on word of mouth and passing of information between beekeeping clubs and enthusiasts.

story:
Sag's Top Surgery!

I've scheduled the surgery for may 2nd 2014!
My name is Sag, and I am a TransFag with a heart of gold. I am a gender queer witch and a radical faerie. I am a sacred clown and an activist. I'm a musician and an artist. I am also none of those things, and mostly just a humble and grateful part of a really mind exploding community. 
I can't fully express in words how important it is to me to get this surgery, and how grateful and intensely happy it makes me that I can reach out to my community like this, and maybe, anything is possible.

So thank you for clicking that link, whether we know each other or not, and thank you for supporting me in whatever way you are available for.


I put up a video, for yall to watch, but you might have to use headphones to hear it:)

My Goal

This time around, I only need to raise 500 dollars for the deposit, and if i raise more than that, it will go to my travel expenses to get from the NW to the bay and back. Eventually, I will need to make 8000 dollars or at least half of that to pay on the day of my surgery.
You can download my music for free regardless of whether or not you donate money to my cause, go to soundcloud.com/sir-queen

The Impact

I would not be able to get this surgery without the support of my community. Y'all are making this possible for me, that I never knew I could accomplish and I would not be where I am today without every single one of you. You are helping me change my life.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you don't have money to contribute, there are other things you can do to help me make this happen! 

  • Share this link on your Facebook! Spread it around to your friends, and other people who want to help a tranimal in need!
  • Any magical or energetic support around making this a reality for me is always appreciated. 

And that’s all there is to it.


Love and Magic,

Sag

Crusty Life Coach CD

story:
Seva Yoga Outreach needs YOUR help to carry out 3 new yoga programs for children and adults in marginalized communities. We bring qualified yoga instructors to underserved communities and teach tools that reduce stress, depression and anxiety. Through practice we see marked improvement in confidence, hopefulness and well-being. We know these tools empower people to take control over their lives and encourage healthy lifestyle choices that create positive changes in their lives as well as the community.

With your help we will deliver free yoga classes, mats and supplies and volunteer support.Participants at the following sites thank you in advance for your help in furthering their wellness through yoga . 

Pinellas Hope is a temporary emergency shelter for over 250 homeless men and women. Background checks are done on all the residents and case managers meet with them on a regular basis to set goals towards self-sufficiency. They also assist the residents with job and housing placement and perform follow up visits with them six months after they leave the shelter.

Family Resources - Transitional Living Program is in place for youth 14-17 years old who, due to dysfunctional families or lack of alternative safe living arrangements, cannot live at home and can benefit from training in independent living skills. TLP provides safe shelter, food and clothing, with educational opportunities, individual and group counseling as well as the training and education necessary to function independently.

RCS Grace House provides dignified apartment-style emergency shelter, to homeless families with children, for up to two months. The program works one-on-one with families through case management, providing education, increasing job readiness, and helping families save money in order to secure stable housing. 90% of families who complete the program move to stable housing. 

Future Vision- 100% Growth (people served), Youth Peer Teacher Program, Comprehensive Volunteer Training and Continued Education, Take away tools for all students.

Click here and learn more About our Founder and Leadership Team

Our students have diverse backgrounds of drug addiction, domestic violence, poverty, mental illness, chronic disease, trauma and unemployment. We see lots of people not in great shape.  Many struggle to simply sit comfortably on the floor because back pain is so intense. We provide a gentle respite and tools to provide comfort and heal.

The daily stresses they grapple with, the challenging and difficult situation in life put the body in a constant fight-or-flight state also known as an over stimulated sympathetic nervous system. This can lead to high blood pressure, anxiety, sleeplessness, and pain. Yoga with its deep breathing helps to release stress from the body.

For many it is a constant struggle to meet daily needs: shelter, food, clothing, and hygiene. Calming the mind can seem impossible. Yoga helps to re-focus the mind. Our teachers create a safe and non-judgmental space to explore ways to improve their health and well-being, and provide a slice of peace and quiet.  The affirmations weaved through class instil hope and courage. On their mat there is common ground.

Most importantly, we recognize the humanity in each and every student, finding love and compassion for all. Through simple words like Namaste, they are reminded that we see the goodness in them and we are all connected. They matter.



"You can never know how timely this was. I feel so relaxed. My anxiety is lighter. I'm going to do some on my own before you come back."

"Thank you for coming here for us. Sleeping on a mat every night takes its toll and this helps."

“Since you started coming here I’ve been really paying attention to what I put in my body and my attitude. I feel a lot less sad.”

“I do it on my own too. I call it tent yoga.”

  • Help us grow our support network by getting the word out and making some noise about our work in the community and THIS campaign. Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Volunteer- we have a number of ways volunteers get get involved. Attend our monthly SYO tea to learn more about us and connect with other like minded individuals. Contact us for an invite and of course bring a friend!

story:
VERSÃO EM PORTUGUÊS - ENGLISH VERSION DOWN BELOW

Como muitos sabem, eu, Laura Veratti, juntamente com Juliana Olm e Ana Luiza Fernandes, trabalhamos por alguns meses na escola Upendo Rescue Centre, na favela de Mukuru, em Nairobi, Quênia. Depois de voltarmos para o Brasil, contamos um pouco do que vivemos e realizamos por lá através de uma exposição de fotos em São Paulo - que nos gerou fundos para investir futuramente na biblioteca da escola. 

Agora essa história tem mais um capítulo: o mês de novembro surpreendeu Nairobi com fortes chuvas; rio que passa por detrás do muro da Upendo subiu significativamente seu nível forçando o muro da escola, que não aguentou e acabou cedendo.

Resultado:
1) A plantação sustentável que fizemos e que era fonte de alimento para as crianças atualmente, foi completamente destruída;
2) Material escolar destruído;
3) A força da água devastou a escola, mudando significativamente o dia a dia dos alunos, sem mencionar a preocupação que nos deixou em relação à saúde das crianças.

Foi com muita tristeza que recebemos a notícia e a dividimos com vocês, pois muitos fizeram parte dessa nossa jornada pelo Quênia e doaram dinheiro para a plantação e para tantos outros projetos realizados. 

Abaixo seguem algumas imagens para melhor compreensão: 

Crianças brincam em frente do muro e da plantação em fase inicial / Children playing in front of the wall and the plantation in it’s initial step -  

Equipe e alunos da Upendo iniciando as plantações / Team and pupils during the plantation process -

Plantação após 1 ano, a escola já conseguia colher o alimento das crianças / Plantation after 1 year, the school started feeding its pupils - 

Rio que fica do outro lado do muro / River on the other side of the wall -

Após inundação, plantação destruída / After the flood, plantation destroyed -

Foto do celular do Teacher Benedict após incidente / Pictures from Teacher Benedict’s phone after the incident -

Material escolar destruído com a enchente / School materials destroyed -


O que é possível e viável fazer agora?

Colocar urgentemente concreto no muro e no chão para que isso não aconteça novamente!

Valor necessário para o serviço: R$2.000,00 
Quem auxiliará na obra: Manuela Müller, alemã que está no Quênia e que dará todo o suporte no processo, monitorando a obra e nos repassando os feedbacks e fotos

Precisamos enviar este dinheiro o quanto antes, para que a escola consiga realizar o trabalho. Por isso, qualquer ajuda, é de grande importância.

Este é apenas o primeiro passo para conseguirmos reconstruir o trabalho de meses que tivemos por lá. E acreditamos que com a ajuda de todos e mesmo à distância, seremos capazes de voltar a fornecer segurança e alimento para as crianças.

Contamos muito com a sua colaboração e agradecemos desde já sua atenção. 

Asante Sana, Muito Obrigada em Swahíli.

Laura, Ana, Juliana e Mariana.

______________________ENGLISH

Upendo Rescue Center (upendo means “love” in Kiswahili) is situated on a small patch of land on the edge of Nairobi’s Mukuru slum. It is a Primary school for orphans and underprivileged children in the slum. Around 300 of the slum’s most disadvantaged children gather here for the education they otherwise would never have received. Many are orphaned; others just desperately poor. The children find at Upendo Rescue Center not only free education but also an alternative to crime and violence as well as positive adult role models.

A few weeks ago we had some really heavy rain at night in Nairobi, which lasted for some hours. The river behind the school came up by around five meters and flooded the slum. Unfortunately the wall in the school wasn't strong enough to hold the water out and collapsed at a particular area.

The flood entered the compound around 70cm high. The water only went down the next morning.

Results:

1)  It was of course very messy and the teachers and elder pupils cleaned up for a good two weeks;

2)  The sustainable plantation built to feed the children was completely destroyed; also the school materials and some furniture;

3)  Children’s health and security was put in danger.

We're quite lucky that nobody died because in other parts of the slum people drowned.
So we're happy about that, but the destruction was big.

Some pictures up above help understanding the situation. 

What is possible to do now?

It is URGENTLY need to add concrete on the wall to avoid this to happen again!

Amount necessary to do the service: $875
Who will help during the process: Manuela Müller, a German volunteer who works in Kenya and helps Upendo Rescue Centre with social projects. She will be responsible to send us feedbacks and pictures from the service.

The money needs to be sent by mid-December! So, any amount donated is really significant!!! To donate, please check on the right side of this page ->

This is our first step to reconstruct everything that was lost with the flood and we believe that with everyone’s help it will be possible to return ensuring security, health and food to the children and teachers who dedicate their time to take so much care about the pupils.

JOIN US NOW IN THIS MISSION.

We thank you in advance! Asante Sana, thanks in Kiswahili, local language.

Laura, Manuela, Ana, Juliana, Mariana and Giuseppe.

Precisamos enviar este dinheiro o quanto antes, para que a escola consiga realizar o trabalho. Por isso, qualquer ajuda, é de grande importância.

Contamos muito com a sua colaboração e agradecemos desde já sua atenção. 
Asante Sana, Muito Obrigada em Swahíli. 

Laura, Ana, Juliana e Mariana.
______________________ENGLISH

Upendo Rescue Center (upendo means
“love” in Kiswahili) is situated on a small patch of land on the edge of
Nairobi’s Mukuru slum. It is a Primary school for orphans and underprivileged
children in the slum. Around 300 of the slum’s most disadvantaged children
gather here for the education they otherwise would never have received. Many
are orphaned; others just desperately poor. The children find at Upendo Rescue
Center not only free education but also an alternative to crime and violence as
well as positive adult role models.
A
few weeks ago we had some really heavy rain at night in Nairobi, which lasted
for some hours. The river behind the school came up by around five meters and
flooded the slum. Unfortunately the wall in the school wasn't strong enough to
hold the water out and collapsed at a particular area.
The
flood entered the compound around 70cm high. The water only went down the next
morning.
Results:

1) 
It
was of course very messy and the teachers and elder pupils cleaned up for a
good two weeks;
2) 
The
sustainable plantation built to feed the children was completely destroyed;
also the school materials and some furniture;
3) 
Children’s
health and security was put in danger. 
We're quite lucky that nobody died because in other parts of the
slum people drowned.
So we're happy about that, but the destruction was big. 


Some pictures up above help understanding the situation. 
What is possible to do now?

It is URGENTLY need to
add concrete on the wall to avoid
this to happen again!
Amount necessary to do
the service: $875
Who will help during the process: Manuela Müller, a German
volunteer who works in Kenya and helps Upendo Rescue Centre with social
projects. She will be responsible to send us feedbacks and pictures from the
service. 
The money needs to be sent by mid-December!
So, any amount donated is really significant!!! To donate, please check on the
right side of this page ->
This is our first step to reconstruct
everything that was lost with the flood and we believe that with everyone’s help it will be possible to
return ensuring security, health and food to the children and teachers who
dedicate their time to take so much care about the pupils. 
JOIN US NOW IN THIS MISSION. 
We thank you in advance! Asante Sana, thanks
in Kiswahili, local language. 
Laura, Manuela, Ana, Juliana, Mariana and Giuseppe.

story:
Bodega Bay Fire Protection District:

The Need: A New Paramedic Rescue Advanced Life Support Ambulance

Current Ambulance Purchasing Plan:

Purchase a 2013 International Leader Type 2 Ambulance. This unit has been a Demo Rig that has 6,000 miles of use therefore it is heavily discounted. (approximately $30,000) Our purchasing plan includes many different revenue streams.

Budget

Total Purchase price: $180,000 (73% FUNDED)

2013 Sonoma County Transient Occupancy Tax Grant $45,000 (FUNDED)

2014 Sonoma County Transient Occupancy Tax Grant $45,000 (FUNDED)

Community Fundraisers $3,000 (FUNDED)

Bodega Bay Firefighters Association Contribution $10,000 (FUNDED)

Surplus of Current Ambulance $10,000 (TBD)

Loan Amount (TBD)

Crowd Sourcing Fundraiser to pay off the Loan that will be need to complete funding $50,000

This Indiegogo fundraising campaign will complete the funding to purchase this much need paramedic ambulance to continue to serve the community and visitors of Bodega Bay, CA

  • FIRE DISTRICT ISSUES:

  • THE RISING COST OF BUSINESS HAS EXCEEDED ANNUAL TAX REVENUE AND RESERVE FUNDS WILL BE DEPLETED IN THE NEAR FUTURE. 

  • A DROP IN STAFFING LEVELS WILL RESULT IN LOWER LEVELS OF SERVICE AND SLOWER RESPONSE TIMES FOR MULTIPLE INCIDENTS.

  • A MAJORITY(65%+) OF THE TOTAL CALLS ARE FOR NON-BODEGA BAY RESIDENTS.

  • CURRENT AMBULANCE IS NO LONGER RELIABLE TO PROVIDE CONSISTENT EMERGENCY MEDICAL RESPONSE.


    DISTRICT BACKGROUND:

  • Established in 1984 because residents wanted a full-time ambulance and fire fighting capability in the area.

  • Provides emergency medical service, fire suppression, rescue, hazardous material response, and public assistance over a 34 square mile area to residents and visitors. 

  • Averages 480 emergency incidents per year; vast majority are for medical aid versus fire suppression.

  • Provides a "Paramedic" ambulance; paramedics have advanced life support training which includes administering IVs and drug therapy, advanced airway techniques, cardiac monitoring, defibrillation, ETC.

  • Paramedic ambulance provides critical link between Bodega Bay and the nearest hospital in Santa Rosa (40 minutes away) and responds to an additional 216 square mile area beyond the fire district boundary.

  • 3 paid staff per shift, including 1 firefighter/paramedic; 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. 

  • Paid staff is augmented with safety volunteers, Non-safety volunteers, reserve firefighter/EMT’s, and firefighter interns in training.

  • The last district fire tax increase was in 2003. The voters rejected a proposed tax increase in April 2014, with resistance focusing on the current high local fire tax and a lack of support from the larger community.

    INFLUENCING FACTORS:

  • Bodega Bay is a tourist destination.  State and County Parks plus commercial properties account for over 4 million visitors a year, which equals almost 11,000 visitors a day.  The resident population according to the census is 1077 (2010).  There is no regular recurring financial support from the State or the County to assist with their portion of the visitor population.

  • The District does not get any revenue from the statewide $150 CalFire fee instituted in 2011.

  • As a post-Prop 13 District, with more than a $650 million assessed value, less than .04% ($226,000) comes from local property taxes.

  • District taxpayers pay a high special fire tax, which accounts for 60% of the District's revenue; a typical residence is $524.40 per year or $44 per month.

  • Over 65% of the "total calls" are to help non-Bodega Bay residents; 80% of medical transports are for non-Bodega Bay residents.

  • Current revenues to do not increase as fast as inflation.

  • Current revenues are not quite enough to pay for 3 personnel for each of the 3 shifts.  National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) recommends 4 firefighters per engine company and 2 firefighters per ambulance.

  • There is little residential or commercial growth expected, which limits new tax revenue and subsequently keeps us from keeping pace with inflation.

  • We have aggressively pursued grants and alternative funding.

  • Our first-out engine and ambulance "service lives" have been extended by aggressive maintenance and retrofits in lieu of preferred replacement; therefore, saving money.

The District does not get any revenue from the

District

Over 65% of the

Current revenues
to do not increase as fast as inflation.

are not quite enough to pay for 3 personnel for each of the 3 shifts.  National Fire Protection Association (NFPA)
recommends 4 firefighters per engine company and 2 firefighters per ambulance.
There is little
residential or commercial growth expected, which limits new tax revenue and
subsequently keeps us from keeping pace with inflation.
We have
aggressively pursued grants and alternative funding.

Our first-out

money.

story:
Dear Friends,

The villages of Boi and Kponkpo are severely underserved communities in the Greater Accra area. In Ghana, hospitals are predominantly found in urban areas, making access very expensive and time consuming for many citizens. On behalf of the Alliance for African Women Initiative, I am raising money to provide basic health services to these towns. In collaboration with Ghana Health Services, we aim to build a single room medical facility in Kponkpo, which will provide the following services:

·  Recurring Malaria treatment

·  Diagnosis and treatment of the recent Cholera outbreak in the Region

·  Ebola screenings and awareness campaigns

·  Child and maternal health services and education

·  Family planning services

·  Child vaccinations

·  General checkups and referrals

In addition to building a health facility, we would like to provide basic medical supplies and equipment to meet patient’s needs. Donations will fund the following:

·  Vaccination fridge

·  Desk and chairs

·  Supplies cabinet

·  Examination bed

·  Blood Pressure Apparatus

·  Baby weighing scale

·  First aid kit

·  Bandages/plaster

·  Thermometer

·  Anti-bacterials and soap

In addition to the qualified health professionals provided by Ghana Health Services, we are also training volunteers from the community to make home visits to assess patient needs. Donations will provide these unpaid volunteers with transportation allowances and access to training and skill-development courses.

The Alliance for African Women initiative is a grassroots NGO based in Accra, Ghana. We are committed to building the capacities of marginalized citizens, predominantly women, children and those living with HIV/AIDS.

For more information please email me at mpolychronis@afawigh.org or check out our website at www.afawigh.org.

Thank you so much for your help!

Maria

story:
When my parents divorced, many things were disrupted. My stay-at-home mother, siblings, and I were dumped on the streets with no money, and thus began many years of living in basements and garages, sleeping on cots in living rooms and sharing bunks with relatives, while my mother struggled constantly to keep our lives as normal as possible. One of the biggest disruptions, though I didn't recognize it at the time, was the loss of our family health/dental plan.

Being homeless for years while our mother worked constantly for scrap change to make sure we had somewhere to sleep at night, bred a lifestyle of surviving off what could be bought cheap. Here in America the healthy food is expensive, and the bad food is affordable. Growing up on microwave dinners and soda seemed normal to me. When you pair this toxic diet with a family history of weak, brittle, soft teeth... You get a recipe for dental disaster.

My teeth were always sensitive, increasingly so as I aged. With no dental care, this spread over time into completely new, far worse complications. Slowly but surely, my teeth got softer and my enamel weakened until even the soft foods would result in chipped teeth. It wasn't until my wisdom teeth came in that the real problems began. These big new teeth, were still healthy and strong, and came in quicker than usual for most kids. Though they began to emerge straight and without complication, there was not enough space in my mouth for them and within a few months my molars began cracking. Before I knew it the cracks were so deep the enamel began to fall apart, leaving the pulp of the tooth and the actual nerves exposed. 

After a night of crying and screaming in excruciating pain, unlike any I had felt before, my older sister couldn't stand it and called an emergency dentist in the area. I was rushed to a small, dimly lit office a few towns away, at about 2am to have a full root canal and extraction. At this point, fearing a root canal was nonsense, anything could be better than this pain. My teeth shattered when the dentist attempted to pull them out, and so he opted for the drill. I had a gaping wound taking up half my jaw for the next couple weeks. From this point on problems slowly spread to other areas, after a while I got used to the pains and aches and did what I could to ignore it all. 

But now it is obvious I need to fix this once and for all. With roughly 18 of my 30 or so teeth in tact, and the pain more often than ever before, the only logical step is to have the wisdom teeth extracted and surrounding areas drilled out.

These donations will go directly toward the surgeries needed to save what's left of my mouth. With a single root canal running close to $1000, and extractions for anywhere between $200 and $600, you can rest assured every cent from this campaign will go towards necessary procedures to stop the pain, nerve damage, jaw problems, and frequent infections resulting from these dental issues. 

I am not asking you to help me pay for something I want, I am asking you to help me enjoy normal life in the ways it was meant to be. I am asking you help me help myself, to set me free from daily pain and hiding smiles, so I can make my own mark in life without being hindered by this.


Donating to this campaign will change my entire life, and could potentially save it in the future. Thank you for your time, and thank you to anyone who helps - I am forever in debt to you.
